ul.li1: 101 Dead flies cause a bad smell and ruinOr “spew” the ointment of the perfumer.
ul.li2: So also a little folly outweighs wisdom and honor.
ul.li1: 2The heart of the wise inclines to his right,
ul.li2: but the heart of the fool inclines to his left.
ul.li1: 3Even when the fool walks along the road, he lacks sense;
ul.li2: he tells everyone that he is a fool.
ul.li1: 4If the anger of the ruler rises against you,
ul.li2: do not leave your post,
for calmness can undo great offenses.
ul.li1: 5There is an evil I have seen under the sun—
ul.li2: it is an error that proceeds from a ruler!
ul.li1: 6The fool is set in many high places,
ul.li2: but the rich sit in lowly places.
ul.li1: 7I have even seen slaves riding on horses
ul.li2: and princes walking like slaves on the earth!

ul.li1: 8Whoever digs a pit will fall into it.
ul.li2: Whoever breaks through a wall, a snake will bite him.
ul.li1: 9Whoever quarriesLiterally “breaks out” stones will be wounded by them.
ul.li2: Whoever splits logs will be endangered by them.

chapter.pericope: Hard Work and Skill Alone Cannot Succeed—Wisdom is Necessary

ul.li1: 10If the ax is blunt but one does not sharpen its edge,
ul.li2: he must exert more effort,Literally “he must be more strength”
ul.li1: but the advantage of wisdom is it brings success.
11If the snake bites before the charming,
ul.li2: the snake charmer will not succeed.Literally “there is no advantage to the owner of the charm”

ul.li1: 12The wise man wins favor by the words of his mouth,
ul.li2: but the fool is devoured by his own lips.
ul.li1: 13He begins by saying what is foolish
ul.li2: and ends by uttering what is wicked delusion.
ul.li1: 14The fool talks too much,Literally “increases words”
ul.li2: for no one knows what will be.
ul.li3: Who can tell anyone what will happen in the future?Literally “after him”
ul.li1: 15The fool is so worn out by a hard day’s work
ul.li2: he cannot even find his way home at night.Or “for he knows not to go to a city”
ul.li1: 16Woe to you, O land, when your king is a youth
ul.li2: and your princes feast in the morning.
ul.li1: 17Blessed are you, O land, when your king is a son of nobility
ul.li2: and your princes feast at the proper time—
ul.li3: to gain strength and not to get drunk.
ul.li1: 18Through sloth the roof sinks in,
ul.li2: and through idleness of hands the house leaks.
ul.li1: 19Feasts are held for celebration,Literally “They make bread for laughter”
ul.li2: wine cheers the living,
ul.li1: 20Do not curse the king even in your thoughts,
ul.li2: and do not curse the rich even in your own bedroom,
ul.li1: for a bird of the sky may carry your voice;
ul.li2: a winged messenger may repeat your words.
